dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so Jerome Powell and the Fed have been making some waves this week, huh? Lotta talk about inflation and what they're gonna do about it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so Jerome Powell and the Fed have been making some waves this week, huh? Lotta talk about inflation and what they're gonna do about it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, totally. I mean, the big takeaway is they're signaling interest rate hikes by the end of 2023. Which, like, is sooner than a lot of people were expecting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, totally. I mean, the big takeaway is they're signaling interest rate hikes by the end of twenty twenty three. Which, like, is sooner than a lot of people were expecting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday signaled that they are looking ahead to two interest rate hikes by the end of 2023sooner than previously expected but not imminentas signs of inflation continue to rattle markets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Not *imminent*, but definitely on the horizon. And it all stems from these inflation signs that are really rattling markets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Not imminent, but definitely on the horizon. And it all stems from these inflation signs that are really rattling markets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday signaled that they are looking ahead to two interest rate hikes by the end of 2023sooner than previously expected but not imminentas signs of inflation continue to rattle markets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. Consumer prices were up 3% in May â€“ that's an eleven-year high! And producer prices, uh, soared a record 7.6% in the same month. That's pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. Consumer prices were up three percent in May - that's an eleven-year high! And producer prices, uh, soared a record seven point six percent in the same month. That's pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Prices for consumer goods rose 5% in Maythe highest jump in 13 yearsand producer prices soared a record 6.6% during the same month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which, you know, makes sense when you think about the Fed's new approach, right? They're aiming for inflation that averages 3% over time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, you know, makes sense when you think about the Fed's new approach, right? They're aiming for inflation that averages three percent over time.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last August, the Fed announced it would aim for inflation that averages 2% over time rather than adjust policy to prevent inflation from rising above that threshold

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! They're, like, much more prepared to tolerate higher prices now than they used to be. It's a big shift in their policy thinking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! They're, like, much more prepared to tolerate higher prices now than they used to be. It's a big shift in their policy thinking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last August, the Fed announced it would aim for inflation that averages 2% over time rather than adjust policy to prevent inflation from rising above that thresholdthat means its much more prepared than it used to be to tolerate higher prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But Powell did say they'd adjust if inflation was moving, quote, "materially and consistently" above that goal. So, they're not just letting it run wild?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Powell did say they'd adjust if inflation was moving, quote, materially and consistently above that goal. So, they're not just letting it run wild?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Powell on Wednesday emphasized that the central bank would be prepared to adjust the stance of monetary policy if confronted with signs that inflation was moving materially and consistently above the Feds goal of a 2% average over time.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, not at all. They're trying to walk that fine line. Plus, they want to see more progress in the labor market first. We're still down, like, 7.2 million jobs since the pandemic started.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not at all. They're trying to walk that fine line. Plus, they want to see more progress in the labor market first. We're still down, like, seven point two million jobs since the pandemic started.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Wednesday, the Fed said it wants to see more progress in the labor market, which is still down 7.6 million jobs since the onset of the pandemic, before it moves to raise rates and tighten policy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's a huge number. And they're clearly trying to avoid, you know, a "taper tantrum" like after 2008. So, lots of notice before any big moves.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a huge number. And they're clearly trying to avoid, you know, a taper tantrum like after two thousand eight. So, lots of notice before any big moves.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To avoid spooking investors and damaging financial markets (and avoid the so-called taper tantrum that followed tighter Fed policy after the 2008 financial crisis), the central bank takes pains to give investors plenty of notice before it changes its policies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they're really trying to be transparent. Powell himself said the reopening process is "unprecedented." Shifts in demand are huge, and those bottlenecks and hiring difficulties could make inflation higher and more persistent than they expect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they're really trying to be transparent. Powell himself said the reopening process is unprecedented. Shifts in demand are huge, and those bottlenecks and hiring difficulties could make inflation higher and more persistent than they expect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The process of reopening the economy is unprecedented, as was the shutdown at the onset of the pandemic, Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell said during a press briefing on Wednesday. As the reopening continues, shifts in demand can be large and rapid and bottlenecks, hiring difficulties and other constraints could continue to limit how quickly supply can adjust, raising the possibility that inflation could turn out to be higher and more persistent than we expect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's the real worry, isn't it? Mohammed El-Erian, the economic adviser, he's been pretty vocal. He thinks if the Fed delays tightening, they'll be forced to, uh, "slam on the policy brakes" later, risking a recession.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the real worry, isn't it? Mohammed El-Erian, the economic adviser, he's been pretty vocal. He thinks if the Fed delays tightening, they'll be forced to, uh, slam on the policy brakes later, risking a recession.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The longer the Fed delays [tightening policy], the greater the threat it will be forced to slam on the policy brakes down the road, wrote Mohamed El-Erian, chief economic adviser at Allianz, in a Bloomberg op-ed published Tuesday. This would, in turn, risk both an economic recession and financial market instability.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A valid concern, for sure. But for now, their prediction for PCE inflation this year is 3.9%, which is up a full percentage point from March. They're also expecting, like, 6% GDP growth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A valid concern, for sure. But for now, their prediction for P C E inflation this year is three point nine percent, which is up a full percentage point from March. They're also expecting, like, six percent G D P growth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 3.4%. Thats the Feds prediction for PCE inflation in 2021up a full percentage point from its March prediction of 2.4%. It expects 7% GDP growth and 4.5%% unemployment for the year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, they see higher prices, but also a pretty strong economy overall. And they're still buying all those bonds, hundreds of billions a month, to support the market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, they see higher prices, but also a pretty strong economy overall. And they're still buying all those bonds, hundreds of billions a month, to support the market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The central bank also said it would purchase $700 billion in government debt and continues to buy $120 billion in bonds per month to support that market.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, no end date on that bond-buying program yet either. It really feels like the Fed is trying to, um, navigate a completely uncharted economic recovery here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, no end date on that bond-buying program yet either. It really feels like the Fed is trying to, um, navigate a completely uncharted economic recovery here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the minutes from its June meeting, the Fed did not specify when it would terminate the bond-buying program.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. A lot of plates spinning for J-Powell and the team right now. It's going to be interesting to see how it all plays out over the next year or two.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. A lot of plates spinning for J-Powell and the team right now. It's going to be interesting to see how it all plays out over the next year or two.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. We'll be keeping an eye on it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. We'll be keeping an eye on it.
